oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: DRAPER-MAYNARD STOCK SOLD AT AUCTION The Receiver of the Draper Maynard Co. sold Its entire stock to liquidate the business, and it was offered at auction on October 12-13, 1937. We join in the widespread regret to see such an old and reliable concern pass out of business, another tragedy of the troubled conditions of the last several years. Our buyers attended this auction. Their original purpose was mainly to bid on the D&M raw materials such as fabrics, leathers and felts. But when they saw the completed D&M athletic equipment going on the auction block at prices far under what the cost would be to make similar quality articles, they dipped in and bought a substantial quantity, made under the D&M brand and in D&M boxes. oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Striking parallel in history of baseball and Draper-Maynard: Draper-Maynard made first baseball glove
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Draper-Maynard made first baseball glove, D&M now first choice of major league players
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: baseball; gloves; Athletics; sports and athletic equipment;
Arthur Irwin; Guy Richards; Billy Rogell; Goose Goslin
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: STRIKING PARALLEL in HISTORY of BASEBALL and DRAPER-MAYNARD DRAPER-MAYNARB MADE FIRST BASEBALL GLOVE D&M NOW FIRST CHOICE OF MAJOR LEAGUE PLAYERS IttM^.Ctotoa^DouUeday marked out the firrt baseball diamond fb Coopers- town, N, Y. fha next year,, 1840, Nathaniel Draper started making gloves and mittens in Plymouth. New Hampshire. Today, ovqr 75% of all major league players use DAM baseball doves and mitts. t*he Detroit Tigers, in their race for the world's ehampionsbip, constantly took the field with at least 7, usually 8, players using DAM gloves or mitts. Hie present D&M factory at Plymouth, W, H. The manner in which the first baseball glove came to be made is most interesting. After the death of Nathaniel Draper, his son, Jason F. Draper, carried on the glove business, but at that time no one dreamed that baseball would ever be played with a glove. However, one day in 1882, one Arthur Irwin, a well known player of his day, was vacationing in Plymouth, N. H., and in talking with Mr. Draper, the question came up as to the possibility of making a glove which could be used in playing the game of baseball. Between them they developed a somewhat crude padded glove for the left hand, only a little bigger than a work glove. Also one for the right hand with no fingers and thumb, so that the ball could be thrown without interference. No one expected there would be any great demand for such a glove. Who of the rugged, mustached teams of that day would take the field with anything but bare hands! But the idea took hold. Players discovered that a glove not only gave protection, but aided in catching the ball. And they weren't long in discovering that the better the glove, the better the protection and catching. A fact just as true today as it was then. A D & M First Baseman's Glove of 1900! The la6t word in baseball gloves — at that time. . From that time, the popularity of Draper-Maynard baseball equipment followed very closely the growth in popularity of baseball itself. The enthusiastic reception accorded the early DAM baseball gloves, led the company to extend its production to other baseball and athletic goods. Arthur Irwin's Glove — the first glove in baseball. It was made by D 6s M. Progressive and on the alert for opportunities to improve its products, D&M has always been receptive to new ideas, which explains the sustained popularity of D & M equipment. This policy led many years ago to the practise of bringing outstanding players to the factory for consultation. No one, D&M reasons, is so well qualified to judge the merits of a glove and suggest improvements in it as the men who play the game day after day almost eight months of every year. Consequently, D&M 'representatives contact the teams at their Spring training camps and constantly during the season at the various ball parks. As a result, the D&M line of gloves and other baseball equipment represents and embodies the best of the ideas and features continually being developed for major league players. It is of great significance that D&M pays no royalties for the endorsement of its gloves and no cash bonuses for advertising contracts with players. The players use them because they actually prefer them, having been responsible for their design. It's a far cry from the old *'Knickerbockers" of New York, the "Eckfords" of Nathaniel Draper's first glove plant. Brooklyn, the famous "Domestics" of Newark, the Troy "Haymakers" and other old-time clubs. Draper-Maynard has seen these and hundreds of other teams come and go, happily to be succeeded by new ones fired by the growing popularity and sport of the game. And it's an equally far cry from Irwin's first glove to the present D&M G98. Draper- Maynard is naturally very proud of its close association with the grand old game down through the years, and the fact that it has always been the one outstanding name in baseball for the real ball players. One of the most popular present-day fielder's ^gloves — the well-known D 85 M G98. Some time ago, a group of several of today's most prominent players were inspecting the D&M line in the factory at Plymouth, New Hampshire. The conference ended with this remark by Bill Werber: "When better gloves are made, D&M will make 'em!" "In fact, they have been making them for years," piped up Lefty Grove, "and still are, if you ask me!" The trade mark that has identified the best in athletic equipment since the beginning of organized sport. Guy Richards of D 8b M * talking it over" with three Detroit Tiger Champions. Can you name them?

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: 66 JOHN B. VARICK CO., MANCHESTER, N. H. No. 190 D&M OFFICIAL. LEAGUE BASE BALL Unconditionally Guaranteed for Eighteen Full Innings **:. Absolutely every detail conforms exactly to the specifications of the American and National League. Each Ball is guaranteed perfect in ?ize, weight, durability and resiliency. D&M's long experience in making baseballs has enabled them to perfect special winding machinery which eliminates softness and assures perfect roundness. The center is pure para rubber or cork and rubber. Nothing but pure blue and white virgin wool yarn is used, each winding is made at a special approved tension which gives the right resiliency. During the several windings of sized wool yarn the balls are weighed and measured several times for possible variation. Over the finish winding of Sea Island cotton is a thin layer of rubber cement which thoroughly waterproofs the in: ide and allows the cover to lay firm and even. Only the finest alum tanned horsehide covers go into the Official Ball. They must be of an exact thickness and toughness. Every Ball is hand i ewed with the strongest red and green thread obtainable. The D&M Official Ball has been adopted in leagues throughout the world because of its extreme long service. LEAGUE BASE BALL The new construction of this ball insures perfect balance and perfect resiliency. It has finer playing and wearing qualities. Those who used this ball during the 1925 World Series and in other games consider it the greatest improvement ever known in Base Ball making—as perfect as a ball can be. This new center is made of a lathe turned perfect sphere of live cork surrounded by black semi-vulcanized rubber over which is vulcanized another cover of red rubber, forming a core remarkable for its accuracy in proportions and for its action in preserving the liveliness of the ball. Another important feature is the high grade, pure wool yarn, spun in our own plant and wound by specially constructed machines. The covers are selected from the best horse hides and stitched with extra strong red and blue thread. Each ball exactly conforms with official specifications making it Official for all games. Guaranteed to last a full game. . $2.00 No. O. N. C. HARDWOOD BASE BALLS NATIONAL LEAGUE—Made of fine wool yarn, wound on a cork and rubber center, double horse hide cover. WE invited these men to our plant, where they saw all the materials that enter into the D&M goods, saw all the process of manufacture, suggested changes in designs, etc. We have made the D&M goods conform to the ideas and experience of these practical players who know when a thing is right, and in their honor we have named many of the D&M goods for them. Everett Scott
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: A great player's experience with a "Lucky Dog" Glove Same Glove Now Scott Likes the D & M THE DRAPER-MAYNARD CO., Plymouth, N. H. Gentlemen. I am sending by parcel post an old glove which I would not take $25.00 for now. I want you to put a new face on this glove if you can possibly do so and also would like to have a new glove made of the same leather and after the same model. With the old glove I am sending, I made two World Records for short stops. Much of my success is due to the D&M Glove. (Signed) EVERETT SCOTT 326 "West 11th St., Auburn, Ind. Scott's two World Records are : First, a remarkable run of thirty-two straight games including one hundred and ninety-one chances without an error. Second, a season's fielding average of nine hundred and seventy-six, which is about eight points more than ever made before by a short stop playing in over one hundred games. He has led the American League in fielding for three years. _____ Have you had your copy of the new edition "Official Rules for Baseball and Tennis" ? Send for it. No charge. DRAPER-MAYNARD COMPANY Dept. C, Plymouth, N. H.

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: IV THE COMPANION FOR ALL THE FAMILY March 3,1921 The "Lucky Dog" Kind DID you ever before see any baseball goods so written over with the names of famous players? These are big men and they deserve all the fame that has come to them—they won it by honest endeavor. The D & M won their indorsement by the same means and we are proud to have succeeded in making baseball goods that command the O. K. of such men. Many articles in the D & M "Lucky Dog" line are made after ideas suggested by these players—ideas gained by them in their own experience on the ball field. We are glad to share with them the credit for the wonderful growth of the D & M sporting goods business, a growth unsurpassed in the history of baseball. In buying any article of D & M make you can feel absolutely sure that you are getting the best, and that there is a strong house and an ironclad guarantee back of every article you buy. The D & M "Lucky Dog" line embraces everything for sports. Whether it be baseball, football, basket ball, soccer ball, volley ball, tennis, punching bag, boxing, bathing, track work or a hike, you will find in the D & M line the equipment you want at the price you want to pay. The D &* M Catalogue is a veritable picture book, brimful of interest for every lover of out- of-door fun. You should be sure to get a new copy every Spring and Fall The Catalogue for Spring and Summer of 1921 is waiting for you now. oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: sports and athletic equipment; gloves; mitts; rackets; baseballs;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: March 13, 1919 THE COMPANION FOR ALL THE FAMILY 139 Soldiers call them the "Lucky Dog" Sport Goods One secret of better baseball is in using better baseball goods—here they are. *T\0 you know why the American boys turned **** the tide that won the war ? It was not that they were trained soldiers—for they were not— but they were trained in alertness, in team work and quickness of judgment; in accuracy of aim and in that sense — whatever you call it —that anticipates what the other fellow is going to do and does it first. They had all kinds of courage. They knew no fear, and they wouldn't be beaten. It was the old baseball spirit adapted to a new use. The preparation for thjs war had been going on for years on every "diamond," "gridiron," school ground, and in vacant lots and back yards all over America. All of these qualities that helped to win the war will help anyone to win in peaceful pursuits. With the world's new appreciation of sports, D & M Sport Goods should be of greater service than ever. The goods shown here are just a few of the good things in the new D & M line. We furnish everything for sports and the quality always exceeds the price. If you would do better business, sell more goods, accomplish more work, excel in your profession or lead your class in school, take some time for sports. And if you would like to play better baseball you should have our new edition of Official Rules for Baseball and Tennis There's a copy of these Rules and a new Catalogue Free for every man, boy or girl who will send for them. This Catalogue is of exceeding interest—one of the best we ever published. Find the article you want and if your dealer hasn't it send to us—but ask him first THE DRAPER-MAYNARD COMPANY Dcpt. oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: SPORT GOODS-SNOW TOGS Now let us get this straight. Ed Maynard's Sport Goods and' Snow Togs are made in Plymouth, N. H. The Pilgrims DIP NOT lrnd there. Plymouth Rock is NOT situated in town. It had to be near the seacoast. The Mayflower DID NOT anchor in our harbor because we haven't any harbor. Mary Chilton WAS NOT the first white woman to land there. That was in Plymouth, Massachusetts. President Coolidgc WAS NOT born in this town. That's in Vermont. But we think Plymouth, N. HL, is a mighty good town in spite of our lack of Historical events. We have as good, if not better, neighbors than any other town. Our visitors are of the kind that make us proud to have them around. Our weather is regular New England weather. There is a lot of it and there is nothing unusual about it. 90 per cent, of all the weather in the world passes through our Main Street every February. It is then distributed to the weaker communities in diluted doses. We can show you more varieties of weather in any given space of time than almost any place, elsewhere. We have plenty of good ski tows and lots of room all around. The Plymouth Swiss Ski School is worth a visit. Milty runs it. If we were able to suck as hard as the Chambers of Commerce in the South and West can blow, we would have the whole pooulation of the United States in New Hampshire inside of two weeks. ED MAYNARD WANTS TO SEE YOU SO DOES JACK

oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: D. &M. THRIBBLED SEAMED STRIKING BAGS. Each bag is sewed in usual- manner, after which a strip of 10-oz. duck is sewed on inside of bag over seam, which covers all rough edges and gives protection to the bladder. This strip of duck is sewed through the bag each side of original seam, preventing all danger from the bag ripping. All loops are of rawhide leather, covered and stitched with same leather as bag. Only the best pure gum bladders are used in these bags, which are guaranteed to have no imperfections. Made with one or two loops. Retail, $2.50 to $5.00 each. SEND FOR CATALOGUE. D. & M.
